Award.AwardTitle: Sources of soil organic matter transported by soil erosion in fire-prone upland ecosystems of the Sierra Nevada
Award.AbstractNarration:
Lateral redistribution of soil organic matter (OM) by erosion controls soil carbon stocks, stability, and mechanisms of stabilization in both natural and anthropogenically disturbed ecosystems. Little is known about the interactive effects of erosion and fire on dynamics of soil OM. Yet it is critical to understand how the coupled processes of fire and erosion affect stability and stabilization mechanisms of soil OM in fire-prone ecosystems because stability and stabilization mechanisms of soil OM (including the association of OM with soil minerals physically through aggregation and chemically through complexation of organic functional groups with metal oxides) determine 1) amount of soil OM that is combusted during fires, 2) proportion of soil OM that is redistributed and mineralized during erosional transport of sediments downhill, and 3) stability of eroded and deposited soil OM. In this project, we aim to determine the effect of watershed size and source of eroded OM on soil OM dynamics primarily in the Kings River Experimental Watershed in California.

It is critical to develop an understanding of the pedologic, hydrologic, climatic, and geomorphic factors that control variability in source of eroded organic matter (OM), as these factors can influence concentration and composition of OM mobilized by soil erosion, and its enrichment in eroded sediments. This, in turn, has significant implications for determining whether erosion renders fire-affected ecosystems sources or sinks for atmospheric carbon dioxide. In addition to tackling these questions, data collected as part of this study will serve as benchmark for studying the effect of prescribed forest fires on soil OM dynamics over short and long timescales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Award Title: Sources of soil organic matter transported by soil erosion in fire-prone upland ecosystems of the Sierra Nevada

Federal Award ID: 1147977

Report Submission Period: 2012-2015

Project Outcome

Topsoil and associated soil organic matter are continuously redistributed on the landscape by soil erosion. Soil erosion can induce a sink of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) in soil if at least some of the eroded carbon (C) is replaced by production of new photosynthate or some of the eroded C is stabilized in downslope depositional landform positions. To date, however, there is very little data on the sources of the soil C that is laterally distributed by soil erosion. In this study, we used stable and radioactive isotopes of C (13C and 14C) and the stable isotopes of nitrogen (15N) to determine the origins of sediments and associated soil organic matter eroded from low-order catchments along the western slopes of the Sierra Nevada of California, USA. We found that most of the soil organic matter in eroded sediments was composed of relatively fresh, O-horizon material and had high C concentrations. Our results suggest that surface erosion, as opposed to channeling through established streams and episodic mass wasting events, is likely the largest source of sediment and C exported out of these minimally disturbed catchments. The erosional export of sediment with a high concentration of C and N, especially in the form of undecomposed litter from the forest floor, suggests that a large fraction of the exported C is likely to be decomposed during or after erosion, putting in to question the likelihood that soil erosion could serve as a sink for atmospheric CO2 in such temperate forest ecosystems. 

The following specific outcomes are associated with the project:

Publications: We already published 2 journal papers form this project (Biogeosciences and Nature Education Knowledge), and have additional 1 paper submitted to an academic journal and 1 paper in preparation to be submitted over the coming month. 

Conference Presentations: Findings of from this project were presented in 8 national and international conferences. In addition, results of this work were included in 9 different invited talks delivered in different academic and research institutions, and meetings. 

Faculty Development: This project significantly developed the research capacity of Dr. Berhe's group at UC Merced. In addition to enabling novel scientific advancements in our understanding of soil organic matter dynamics in eroding systems, this project allowed for development of research ideas and preliminary data that were used to support further research by the PI and co-PIs. This was the first lead-PI NSF proposal funded for Berhe. 

Student Development: The project provided funding that supported work of two Masters and two undergraduate students at UC Merced. All the students successfully completed their education at UC Merced. Both the graduate students earned their MSc in Environmental Systems under the supervision of PI-Berhe and co-PI Hart. Both the undergraduate students worked primarily in the research group of PI Berhe, but got the opportunity to also work with co-PI Hart on different aspects of the project. All four of the students got a chance to be trained in different aspects of the research process and have pursued employment and further education in related fields within Biogeochemistry.
